title-group.article-title: Failure and reliability analysis of pinned-joint composite laminates: Effects of pin–hole clearance

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, Saudi Arabia
2Mechanical Design and Production Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Zagazig University, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: UA Khashaba, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, PO Box 80200, Jeddah 21589, Saudi Arabia Email: khashabu@zu.edu.eg, khashabu@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study deals with the failure and reliability analysis of cross-ply [0/90]2s glass fiber reinforced epoxy composite pinned-joints. A series of ASTM tests were conducted to study the effect of pin–hole clearance (neat-fit, 50, 100, 200, and 300 µm) on the properties of glass fiber reinforced epoxy composite pinned-joints. Failure analysis was examined using load–displacement diagrams and visual and scanning electron microscope examinations of the fractured specimens. The results showed that the first-peak and ultimate strengths were, respectively, reduced by 33.1% and 15.3% with increase in the pin–hole clearance. The corresponding increase in the ultimate displacement was 10.7% and the reduction of the apparent joint stiffness 27%. Weibull function was used to analyze the scatter in the experimental results and estimate the mean and the 50% survival strengths. Safe design strengths at different reliability levels, characteristic strengths, and the lower bound strengths were estimated using time to first failure concept.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This study is a continuation of our previous work, introduced in Khashaba1, Selmy et al.2, and Khasaba et al.3 and on the mechanical properties of cross-ply glass fiber reinforced epoxy (GFRE) composites with different off-axis angles. In composite aircraft structures, bolted joints are unavoidable and represent areas of localized stress concentrations that can produce localized plastic deformation and eventually cause crack initiation and instability of the part. Clearance in fiber-reinforced polymeric (FRP) composite bolted joints is one of the important factors affecting their performance. Two values of clearances should be stated for the specifications of the bolted joint setup.

The first value is the bolt–washer clearance.4–9 Park4 and Kelly and Hallström5 used neat-fit clearance between the bolt and washer. For aerospace structures, Herrington and Sabbaghian6 and Khashaba et al.7 used washers with inner diameter equal to 1.04 the diameter of M6 bolt (i.e. clearance = 24 µm). Lim et al.8 used washer with 6.5 mm inner and 12.5 mm outer diameters for M6 bolt, i.e. bolt–washer clearance = 0.5 mm, which is double of that used by the investigators.6,7 Tong9 investigates the effect of the relative positions of the bolt and the washer on bearing failure behavior of bolted composite joints with various lateral constraints. Two extreme diametral fit positions, with a positive or negative bolt hole-to-washer clearance, were considered. He used steel bolts with a shank outside diameter of 6.25 mm. The hole–bolt clearance was 0.1 mm. The washer used has an inner diameter of 7 mm and an outer diameter of 16 mm, and the hole–washer clearance was 0.65 mm. Their experimental results showed that the relative location can affect the initial failure loads but not the ultimate failure loads.

The second clearance value is the bolt–hole clearance, which was investigated by many researchers.5,10–26 Bolt–hole clearance causes the damage region to become more localized, due to decreasing contact area, resulting in reduction of the bearing strength.10

For aerospace structures, different bolt–hole clearance values were used by many investigators. DiNicola and Fantle11 mentioned that 50–150 µm is typical for aerospace structures. In the experimental work done by Khashaba et al.,7 a bolt–hole clearance of 100 µm was used (for M6 bolt), which was typically used by Tong9 for a bolt with a diameter of 6.35 mm. Hyer et al.12 gave an upper bound of 1% on bolt–hole clearance. McCarthy and other researchers13–19 reported that clearance values of 0 and 80 µm, which, respectively, equal 0% and 1% of 8 mm bolt diameter, are within current aerospace tolerances. In addition, they used 2% and 3% clearance (160 and 240 µm) values to study the possible effects of out-of-tolerance for aerospace holes (or fasteners) and also non-aerospace applications.

Many researchers studied the behavior of bolted joint in FRP composites with high clearance compared with that used in aerospace applications.20–24 Subramanian and Senthilvelan20 investigated the influence of bolt–hole clearance (200, 400, and 600 µm) on the performance of double-bolted double-lap joints in glass fiber reinforced polypropylene leaf spring. According to their results, the bearing strength reduced with the increase in bolt–hole clearance, while failure strain decreased by decreasing the bolt–hole clearance. Load–deflection curve of the joint also confirmed the increase in bolt displacement for higher bolt–hole clearance values. This behavior was due to the fact that the greater the bolt–hole clearance the smaller the bearing contact area. Accordingly, more concentrated load would act on the bearing surface which facilitated the progression of extensive damage.

Esendemir21 investigated the effect of clearance on bearing strength and failure modes of mechanically fastened woven glass epoxy composite joints with different geometrical parameters. He found that the bearing strength of GFRE specimens with W/d = 2, E/d = 3, and bolt–hole clearance 3.84% decreased by 51.17%. Pierron et al.22 investigated the behavior ±45° woven GFRE pin joints with a diameter of 16 mm and pin–hole clearances ranging from 100 to 2000 µm (i.e. 0.6–11.1% of hole diameter). The load–deflection curves for their configurations had a smooth non-linear shape until a clear load drop-off at failure. They reported that the failure load was decreased by 30% throughout the investigated range of clearance.

McCarthy et al.14,15 studied the effects of bolt–hole clearance on the mechanical behavior of bolted graphite/epoxy composite joints. The joint type was single-bolt, single-lap, which is the standard test configuration in both civilian and military composite joints. Within the investigated range of clearances (0%, 1%, 2%, and 3%), they reported that an increase in the bolt–hole clearance resulted in an increase of the bolt rotation and decrease in bolt–hole contact area, and hence, the joint stiffness decreased.

Damage due to insufficient clearance during fastener installation will affect the strength results. The recommended tolerance of fastener–hole clearance for aerospace structural is +75/−0 µm (ASTM D 5961 and ASTM D 6742). DiNicola and Fantle11 studied the effect of bolt–hole clearance on the bearing strength of composite bolted joints. The composite laminates were toughened graphite-woven FRE with quasi-isotropic and ±45° lay-ups. The bearing strength was determined experimentally at 4% hole deformation (HD) and at the ultimate bearing loads. They used four clearance values, neat-fit, 76, 152, and 279 µm, with 3.18 and 6.35 mm pin diameters. Their results showed that 4% hole deformation strength (HDS) increased as the clearance increased from neat-fit to 76 mm, for both lay-ups. However, for both hole sizes and laminate lay-ups, the 4% HDS decreased as clearance increased from 76 to 279 mm, in some cases by as much as 30%. On the other hand, the maximum bearing stress was found to be independent of clearance.

Kelly and Hallström5 studied the effect of bolt–hole clearance on 4% HDS and ultimate bearing strengths of carbon FRE (CFRE) laminates with [0/45/90/−45]s and [0/45/90/−45]s2 stacking sequences. Three different clearance levels were investigated; neat-fit, 1.55%, and 3.05%, which, respectively, equal 0, 100, and 200 µm clearance values for a bolt diameter of 6.35. They reported that compared to neat-fit clearance specimens, the 4% HDS of the [0/45/90/−45]s laminate decreased by 7% and 19%, respectively, for bolt–hole clearances of 1.55% and 3.05%, while the corresponding reduction in the ultimate bearing strengths were, respectively, 0% and 12%. The decrease in 4% HDS for the [0/45/90/−45]s2 laminate was 1.3% and 6% for bolt–hole clearances of 1.55% and 3.05%, respectively, while the ultimate bearing strength levels remained almost constant and independent of the clearance between the bolt and the hole.

The results of DiNicola and Fantle11 and Kelly and Hallström5 showed that the effect of bolt–hole clearance, in the range of aerospace tolerances, on bearing strength of FRP composite bolted joints had a conflict behavior. This result was attributed to the complex failure mechanisms of FRP composites with various lay-ups. McCarthy et al.13 studied the influence of bolt–hole clearance on the behavior of bolted joints in carbon fiber/epoxy laminates with [45/0/−45/90]5s and [(45/02/−45/90)345/02/−45/0]s stacking sequences. Both protruding head and countersunk bolts with 8 mm diameter were used, with bolt–hole clearances of 0, 80, 160, and 240 µm. Finger-tight (0.5 Nm) and 16 Nm torque levels were applied. The former torque represented the worst-case scenario of a bolt loosened during fatigue loading from an initial fully torqued condition, while the latter was the full recommended torque level. The investigated joint properties were joint stiffness, 2% offset bearing strength, ultimate bearing strength, and ultimate bearing strain. Their results showed that increasing the bolt–hole clearance leads to reduction of the joint stiffness and increases the ultimate strain throughout the tested joints with different configurations. The maximum bearing strengths for finger-tight joints were observed at bolt–hole clearances of 80 and 160 µm for protruding head and countersunk head bolts, respectively.

With the advance of high-performance aircraft, the scatter in the mechanical properties due to usage of brittle composite materials should be characterized. Weibull distribution function has proved to be a useful and versatile means in assessing the reliability of composite structures. The two defining parameters of the Weibull line are shape parameter known as the Weibull slope (inverse measure of the dispersion in experimental results) and the characteristic strength. The Weibull distribution has a wide variety of shapes,27 for example, when the shape parameter (α) is equal to 1, it becomes the two-parameter exponential distribution. For α value near 3, its coefficient of skewness approaches 0 and the function is capable of approximating a normal distribution. Also, the two-parameter Weibull function has the following advantages: (a) the distribution is expressed in a simple function form and is easy to apply, (b) the distribution accurately describes composite static strength and fatigue life and has been widely accepted for composite statistical data analysis, (c) ability to provide reasonably accurate failure analysis and failure forecasts with extremely small samples that reduce testing time and cost, and (d) Weibull analysis provides a simple and useful graphical informative plot of the failure data that is important to the engineer and the manager.28

The main objective of this study is to investigate the failure and reliability analysis of composite pinned-joints using a theoretical model (Weibull distribution function) with experimental results for a guideline of safe design strength, which are not studied yet. Cross-ply composite laminates [0/90]2s with 40 ± 0.5% fiber volume fraction were locally manufactured using hand lay-up technique. A series of ASTM bearing tests were conducted to clarify the effect of pin–hole clearance (neat-fit, 50, 100, 200, and 300 µm) on the first-peak bearing strength, ultimate failure stress, failure displacement, and bearing stiffness. The experimental observations based on the average values are described elsewhere2 and summarized here with new discussions on the failure analysis with the aid of visual and scanning electron microscope (SEM) examinations of the fractured specimens.

In addition, reliability analysis was performed using Weibull distribution function to evaluate the dispersion in the experimental results and 50% survival bearing strength. Time to first failure (TTFF) concept was used to estimate characteristic bearing strength, lower bound bearing strength, and safe design bearing strength at different reliability levels.

sec.title: Specimen preparation
sec.p:
Glass fiber reinforced cross-ply, [0/90]2s, composite laminates were manufactured using the hand lay-up technique. Table 1 presents the constituent materials of a cross-ply laminate. Details about the manufacturing technique were illustrated earlier.1 The ignition technique was used to determine the fiber volume fraction (Vf) of the composite laminates, according to ASTM D3171. The average value of Vf was 40 ± 0.5%. The thicknesses of the cross-ply composite laminates were 3.2 ± 0.1 mm. Table 1.
The constituent materials of GFRE laminate
Material Type
Matrix Araldite PY 1092 (100 part by weight) Hardener HY 1092 (50 part by weight)
Reinforcement E-roving glass fiber linear density = 2.10 g/m
GFRE: glass fiber reinforced epoxy.

sec.title: Bearing tests
sec.p:
Clearance between the bolt and the hole delays the load transfer to the bolt and subsequently the performance of the joint.29 Damage due to insufficient clearance during fastener installation can affect strength results. The recommended tolerance on fastener–hole clearance for aerospace structural is +75/−0 µm (ASTM D 5961 and ASTM D 6742). Table 2 presents the tolerances on bolt and hole for f7/H10 ISO fitting, and the resulting fits, for some sample bolt diameters.13,16,21,25 Table 2.
Bolt–hole clearance (ISO fitting f7/H10)16
dnom (mm) Bolt Hole Bolt–hole clearance
Δdmax (µm) Δdmin (µm) Δdmin (µm) Δdmax (µm) λmin (µm) λmax (µm)
3–6 −22 −10 0 +48 10 70 (2.3% of 3 mm)
6–10 −28 −13 0 +58 13 86 (1.4% of 6 mm)
18–24 −41 −20 0 +84 20 125 (0.7% of 18 mm)
d, diameter; λ, clearance.

A series of pin bearing ASTM D 5961 tests were conducted on the cross-ply GFRE composite laminates, with different pin–hole clearance values, using universal testing machine (Testometric 200 kN) at ambient conditions. The machine is fully computer controlled and allows for acquisition of load and displacement. Standard dimensions of the test specimen, Figure 1, were chosen according to ASTM D 5961 to obtain bearing failure mode rather than the net tension or shear-out modes.30 The test fixture is illustrated in Figure 2. Joint stiffness, first-peak bearing strength, ultimate strength, and failure displacement were estimated experimentally. Figure 1.
Dimensions of pinned-joint specimens (all dimensions are in mm).
Figure 2.
Pinned-joint fixture.7.

The clearance values were neat-fit, 50, 100, 200, and 300 µm, which represented percentage clearances, λ = 0, 0.83, 1.67, 3.33, and 5% of the pin diameter, respectively. Clearance is defined here as (1)λ=Dh-DpinDpin where λ is the pin–hole clearance, Dh the hole diameter, and Dpin the pin diameter. According to Table 2,13,16,25 ASTM D 5961 and ASTM D 6742, the first two clearance values (neat-fit and 50 µm) are within aerospace tolerances, while the latter two are slightly outside. The latter two clearance values were used to study the possible effects of out-of-tolerance for aerospace holes (or fasteners), and also in non-aerospace applications.13–15

The bearing stress was calculated from equation (2). (2)σb=PDh·t where P is the failure load and t the specimen thickness. In accordance with the ASTM D 5961 standard, the actual thickness (in the vicinity of the hole) and hole diameters for each individual joint were used in the calculations, rather than nominal values.13 Five tests were implemented for each clearance value and the mean values were used to construct the various relationships. The bearing load was applied along the axis of the specimen at a crosshead speed of 2 mm/min until fracture. Irisarri et al.26 reported that compared to the conventional definitions of bearing failure based on a 2% offset strength criterion or the alternative 4% HD, the first-peak bearing load presented the advantage of being physically based, whereas the standard criteria concealed variable and possibly significant levels of damage in the joint. Therefore, in this study, the failure load (P) was defined by two different levels and hence two failure criteria were used to define the failure load (P) level. The first criterion (first peak) used the load at the first peak on the load–displacement curve, Figure 3(a), to calculate the bearing strength,26,31,32 while the second criterion used the maximum load on the load–displacement curve to estimate the ultimate strength.4,5,20,26,33,34 Figure 3.
Load–displacement diagrams (a) and photographs (b) of some fractured pinned-joint specimens with different pin–hole clearances.

sec.title: Load–displacement and bearing stiffness behavior
sec.p:
The load–displacement diagrams of pinned-joint specimens with different pin–hole clearances are illustrated in Figure3(a). The main characteristics of these diagrams are the linear behavior up to a load equal to about 70% of the first-peak load. The linear portion is followed by non-linear behavior up to the first peak. The non-linear behavior is due to the failure of fiber–matrix interface at the pin–hole contact area and the non-linear shear behavior of the GFRP composites.1 Progressive loading leads to ‘brooming’ failure at the edge of the hole at which the first peak on the load–displacement curve is observed. The load subsequently increases in a non-linear fashion accompanied with several peaks up to the ultimate fracture load. Figure 3(b) shows some photographs of fractured pinned-joint specimens with different clearance values. Details about the failure sequence will be discussed later. Figure 4 shows that the failure displacements of GFRE specimens with different pin–hole clearances have approximately constant failure load based on first-peak failure criterion. On the other hand, the failure displacement corresponding to the ultimate load is increased by 10.7% with increase in the pin–hole clearance from neat-fit to 50 µm. After that, it seems to be independent of the clearance value. This behavior is due to the decrease in bearing contact area due to increase in bolt–hole clearance. Accordingly, more concentrated load acts on the bearing surface which facilitates the progression of extensive damage.20 The increasing of pin–hole clearance delays the load transfer to the pin and subsequently increases the ultimate displacement and reduces the apparent joint stiffness by 27% in the investigated range of clearance (Figure 5). Figure 4.
Ultimate and bearing failure displacements of pinned-joint specimens with different pin–hole clearances.
Figure 5.
Bearing stiffness of pinned-joint specimens with different pin–hole clearances.

sec.title: Failure mechanisms
sec.p:
The number of peaks on the load–displacement curves denotes the complexity of failure mechanisms of pinned-joint GFRE composite laminates. The failure sequences of cross-ply composite joint with excessive clearance 300 µm are illustrated in Figure 6. The in-plane shear failure at (1) is due to the circumferential (tangential) stress near the end of the contact region.12,14,15 The in-plane shear failure was at an angle approximately equal to 45° due to excessive clearance, which leads to change in the direction of the circumferential stress. Hyer et al.12 reported that the direction of the peak circumferential stress changed with clearance, which could affect the joint strength. Figure 6.
Visual examination of fractured specimen with 300 µm clearance.

Figure 7 illustrates the SEM examination of GFRE composite pinned-joint specimen with neat-fit clearance at the pin–hole contact area. Figure 7(a) clearly indicates the damage of the matrix and fiber–matrix interface failure of 0o layers due to the bearing load. The compressive load on these layers leads to buckling of 0o fibers/layers resulting in brooming failure mode accompanied with lateral displacement, which contributes in the occurrence of interlaminar shear between 0o and 90o layers, Figure 7(b). The interlaminar shear failure is assisted by the strain differences between the two adjacent layers. Figure 7.
SEM examination of fractured specimen with neat-fit clearance. SEM: scanning electron microscope.

sec.title: Bearing and ultimate strengths
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the effect of pin–hole clearance on the mean first-peak bearing strength and the mean ultimate strength of pinned-joint GFRE composite laminates. The figure indicates that increase in the pin–hole clearance (from neat to 300 µm) results in reduction in the first-peak bearing strength by 33.1%. The corresponding reduction in ultimate strength was 15.3%, which is approximately 50% of the reduction in the first-peak strength. As shown from the literature, the effect of clearance on the ultimate strength has various behaviors depending on the laminate configuration and the constituent materials. DiNicola and Fantle11 reported that the maximum bearing stress for graphite-woven FRE with quasi-isotropic and ±45° lay-ups was independent of bolt–hole clearance. On the other hand, Kelly and Hallström5 showed that increasing the bolt–hole clearance from neat-fit to 200 µm resulted in a 12% reduction in the ultimate strength of CFRE composite laminate with [0/45/90/−45]s stacking sequence. Figure 8.
Effect of pin–hole clearance on mean bearing and ultimate strengths of pinned-joint GFRE composites. GFRE: glass fiber reinforced epoxy.

The reduction of pinned-joint strength with increasing clearance is due to the reduction of the pin–hole contact area that causes the damage region to become more localized, accompanied with increasing radial and bearing stresses.19 McCarthy15 found that the maximum circumferential (tangential) stress, which is near the end of the contact region, increased with increasing pin–hole clearance. This result was another reason for decreasing bearing and ultimate strengths with increasing pin–hole clearances. It is of considerable interest to note that although specimens with pin–hole aerospace tolerances (clearance = 50 µm) have lower values of ultimate strength compared to the neat-fit specimens, they have higher failure displacement. Accordingly, these specimens have higher energy absorption, which plays an important role in delaying the catastrophic failure (Figures 3(a) and 4).

sec.title: Statistical analysis using Weibull distribution function
sec.p: The mechanical properties of composite materials have a remarkable scatter even when manufactured and tested under the same conditions. In the past, the dispersion in the mechanical properties was treated by considering a high safety factor, which increases the material weight, size, and cost. The reliable space and aircraft composite structure requires precision design creation, especially if the structure contains a critical component where any failure is catastrophic. Accordingly, the design criterion for these applications is not only to select stress levels to guarantee that the object will never fail but also to insure that the body survives for the time period required for its intended usage.27

sec.title: Scatter in the experimental results
sec.p: The two-parameter Weibull distribution function, equation (3),27,35 was used to investigate the statistical and reliability analyses of the experimental results of GFRE composite pinned-joints with different pin–hole clearances. (3)F(xi;β,α)=1-exp {- (xiβ )α },β≥0,α≥0 where F(xi; β, α) is the probability of failure, which represents the probability that the fracture strength is equal to or less than xi,36 and β and α are, respectively, the scale and shape parameters of Weibull distribution function.

The reliability (probability of survival), R(xi; b, c), that is the probability that the fracture strength is at least xi can be obtained by rewriting equation (3) as (4)F(xi;β,α)+R(xi;β,α)=1⇒R(xi;β,α) =exp {- (xiβ )α } The values of β and α can be determined by rewriting equation (3) in the form of a straight line as follows (5)ln(xi)=1αln (ln (11-F(xi;β,α) ) ) +ln (β ), which is in the form of; y=bz+a where y = ln(xi), b = 1/α, a = ln(β), and z = ln ln[1/(1 − F(xi;β, α))]. The two variables in equation (5) are the experimental data of bearing strength ‘xi = σbi’ which sort ascending and the mean rank, F(xi; β, α), which can be calculated from equation (6) (6)F(xi;β,α)=in+1 where n is the total number of samples in each test and i the failure order (i = 1 corresponds to the smallest strength and i = n the largest strength).

The mean values of bearing and ultimate strengths (M[x]) and the coefficient of variation (CV) can be calculated from equations (7) and (8), respectively27 (7)M[x]=β·Γ (1+1α )
(8)CV=βΓ (1+2/α )-Γ2 (1+1/α )M[x] where Γ is the gamma function. The values of α, β, and CV% were estimated from the experimental data and are presented in Table 3. Table 3.
Weibull parameters and coefficient of variation for strength results
Clearance (µm) First-peak failure Ultimate failure
α β CV% α β CV%
0 21.21 233.815 5.855 21.608 352.19 5.750
50 10.065 200.956 11.958 7.6291 341.43 15.509
100 17.795 178.719 6.939 11.438 328.93 10.594
200 17.736 163.840 6.961 13.007 322.62 9.374
300 16.649 155.109 7.398 13.475 293.79 9.063

The scatter in the experimental results can be measured by the coefficient of variation (CV) and/or the inverse of the shape parameter, α (slope of the straight line that is drawn in the Weibull probability plotting paper and fits the experimental results). The abscissa in the Weibull paper is ln(σb), while the ordinate ln ln[1/(1 − F(xi;β, α))].

Figures 9 and 10 show the Weibull distributions for first-peak bearing strength and ultimate strength, drawn in the Weibull probability plotting paper, for GFRE composites with different pin–hole clearances. The blue lines (with the smallest slope) in Figures 9 and 10 and the results in Figure 11 indicate that specimens with 50 µm clearance have the highest scatter (highest CV%) compared to the other clearance values. The high scatter in the first-peak bearing strength and ultimate strength for specimens with 50 µm clearance was due to the conflict behavior of the pinned-hole strength in the range of aerospace tolerances, which is stated in the literature.5,11 Figure 9.
Weibull first-peak bearing strength distribution.
Figure 10.
Weibull ultimate strength distribution.
Figure 11.
Coefficient of variation (CV%) versus pin–hole clearance of pinned-joint composite laminates.

Figure 11 and Table 3 show the variation of CV% with pin–hole clearance for the first-peak strength and the ultimate strength results. The figure indicates that the changes of CV% with pin–hole clearance of ultimate and first-peak bearing strengths have the same qualitative behavior. Quantitatively, the first-peak results have lower CV% than the ultimate strength. This result was due to the complex failure mechanisms of pinned-joint GFRE composite laminates.

sec.title: Safe design bearing strength based on TTFF concept
sec.p:
Safe design bearing strength (βR) at different reliability levels, characteristic bearing strength (β∧), and the lower bound bearing strength (βγ) were estimated based on TTFF concept from equations (9) to (11), respectively27 (9)βR=β∧SM·SN·SR
(10)β∧= (∑m=1 ixi αnm )1αn
(11)βγ=β∧SM where m is the finite sample size. In this study, m = 2 (the first two lowest bearing strengths). SM, SN, and SR are the sample size factor, fleet size factor, and reliability factor, respectively. αn is the normalized shape parameter, which is estimated by plotting the normalized bearing strength values (xi/β) in Weibull probability paper with abscissa equal to ln(σb/β) and the ordinate equal to ln ln[1/(1 − F(σb/β))]. The values of β in Table 3 were used for normalizing the experimental results.

Figures 12 and 13 illustrate the Weibull distribution of the normalized first-peak and ultimate strengths, respectively. The values of αn equal the slope of the straight lines that fits the normalized strengths. It is of great interest to note that the slope of the normalized first-peak strengths is higher (i.e. low scatter) than that for the normalized ultimate strength results. The results in Figures 12 and 13 confirm the results in Figures 9 and 10, respectively. Figure 12.
Weibull normalized first-peak bearing strength.
Figure 13.
Weibull normalized ultimate strength distribution.

The values of scatter factors SM, SN, and SR were calculated as follows (12)SM= (12mXγ 2 (2m ) )1αn
(13)SN= (1n )-1αn
(14)SR= (ln (1R ) )-1αn where χ2γ(2 m) is the chi-squared distribution with 2 m degrees of freedom = 13.277 at confidence level γ = 99 %, n the number of tests for each conditions, and R the reliability. Two values of R were considered. The first value of R = 0.368 was estimated from equation (5) by substituting xi = β. This reliability level indicates that 36.8% of the tested specimens have a bearing strength that is at least equal to β.27,35,36 In this case, SR = 1. The second value of R = 0.99 was considered for a high reliability level.

Bearing strength (x) at 50% survival (failure) can be determined either from equation (5) by compensation for the value of F(xi;β, α) by 0.5 or from Figures 9 and 10. The results are illustrated in Figures 14 and 15 for first-peak bearing and ultimate strengths, respectively. The values of 50% survival (failure) mean that 50% of the specimens will survive at the estimated (x). Figure 14.
Safe design first-peak bearing strength of pinned-joint specimens with different pin–hole clearances.
Figure 15.
Safe design ultimate strength of pinned-joint specimens with different pin–hole clearances.

Figure 14 shows the safe design first-peak bearing strength (βR, β∧, and βγ) of pinned-joint composite laminates with different clearance values. The safe design of ultimate strengths of pinned-joint composite laminates with different pin–hole clearance are illustrated in Figure 15. The results in Figures 14 and 15 show that the penalties paid to gain safe design bearing strength (σb,R = 0.99) calculated at high confidence level γ = 0.99 and high reliability R = 0.99 ranged from (33.14–35.28%) and (40.26–44.58%) for first-peak bearing strength and ultimate strength, respectively. The penalty paid to gain high-reliability first-peak bearing strength is lower than that paid for ultimate strength, which has higher CV% and lower normalized shape parameter (Figure 13). This result confirms that the penalty paid to gain high reliability strength is directly proportional to the scatter in the experimental results and the reliability level.

The penalty paid to gain safe design bearing strength is essential for space and aircraft applications, where any failure is catastrophic. The calculated procedure of safe design bearing strengths based on TTFF can work as a role model for the designer with bolted joints in composite structures.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Based on the study, the following remarks can be made:
The load–displacement diagrams of pin-loaded specimens with different pin–hole clearances showed a linear behavior up to about 70% of the first-peak load, followed by non-linear behavior up to the first peak. The load subsequently increased in a non-linear fashion accompanied with several peaks up to the ultimate load. This behavior had been interpreted in light of the visual and SEM examinations of the fractured specimens.
Increasing the pin–hole clearance up to 300 µm resulted in reduction in the first-peak bearing strength and ultimate strength by 33.1% and 15.3%, respectively, compared to specimens with neat-fit clearance. This result was due to reduction of pin–hole contact area due to the hole oversize that caused the damage region to become more localized, resulting in increasing radial and bearing stresses. In addition, the increasing maximum circumferential (tangential) stress, which was ahead the contact region, with increasing pin–hole clearance was another reason for decreasing bearing and ultimate strengths.
The increasing of pin–hole clearance delayed the transferred load to the pin and subsequently increased the ultimate displacement of the GFRE composite joints by 10.8% and reduced the apparent joint stiffness by 27%, compared to the neat-fit specimens.
Although specimens with pin–hole aerospace tolerances (clearance = 50 µm) had lower values of ultimate strength compared to the neat-fit specimens, they had higher failure displacement. Accordingly, these specimens showed higher energy absorption, which could play an important role in delaying the catastrophic failure.
Weibull distribution function was used to analyze the scatter in the experimental results and estimate the mean and the 50% survival first-peak bearing strength and ultimate strength of pinned-joint GFRE composite laminates.
Safe design strength at different reliability levels, characteristic strength, and lower bound strength were estimated based on TTFF concept. The penalty paid to gain high reliability strength is directly proportional to the scatter in the experimental results and the reliability level. The penalties paid to gain safe design bearing strength (σb,R = 0.99) calculated at a high confidence level γ = 0.99 and high reliability R = 0.99 were (33.14–35.28%) and (40.26–44.58%) for first-peak bearing strengths and ultimate strengths, respectively.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
